The State Administrator shall establish a Problem Resolution Office with officers authorized to investigate taxpayer complaints and halt collection activity if deemed non-compliant with the law. Reversal of such injunctions requires approval from the highest tax authority official or General Counsel based on clear evidence, with no delegation allowed. Officers are protected from discipline unless a pattern of unreasonable injunctions is proven. The authority to reverse administrative injunctions may not be delegated. Problem Resolution Officers are protected from discipline unless a pattern of issuing unreasonable injunctions is proven. State Administrators and taxpayers can pursue legal remedies in court. SEC. 53. JURISDICTION AND INTERSTATE ALLOCATION. Allocation of revenue between administering states from taxes imposed by this subtitle is based on the destination of taxable property or services. The Secretary will establish an Office of Revenue Allocation to resolve disputes among states regarding revenue allocation. The Administrator's determination can be reviewed in federal court under an abuse of discretion standard. The destination of taxable property for revenue allocation among states is determined by the Administrator of the Office of Revenue Allocation, subject to judicial review under an abuse of discretion standard. Tangible personal property is allocated based on the state where it was delivered to the purchaser, while real property is allocated based on its location. Other property is allocated based on its destination. The destination of taxable property for revenue allocation is determined by the Administrator of the Office of Revenue Allocation. Tangible personal property is allocated based on delivery location, real property on its location, and other property on the purchaser's residence. Services are allocated based on where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed, with telecommunications services allocated based on the purchaser's residence. The destination of telecommunications and transportation services for revenue allocation is determined based on the residence of the purchaser. Domestic transportation services are allocated to the final destination of the trip within the United States, while international transportation services are allocated based on the final destination or origin outside the United States. The destination of financial intermediation services is the residence of the purchaser. State Tax Administrators have jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination in their state. The State Tax Administrator has jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination in their state, which is not exclusive. The destination of rents and royalties for tangible property leases is where the property is located. For vehicles, the destination is based on the term of the lease or rental. The destination of rent and lease payments for vehicles depends on the term of the rental. For rentals of one month or less, it is where the vehicle was delivered to the lessee. For rentals longer than one month, it is the residence of the lessee. "SEC. 54. Tax to be stated and charged separately." The sales tax must be charged separately from the purchase price by the vendor for taxable property or services. The vendor must provide a receipt with specific details including the price exclusive of tax, amount of tax paid, price inclusive of tax, tax rate, date of sale, vendor's name, and registration number. The tax rate is calculated by dividing the tax paid by the property or service price inclusive of tax. Information required on the receipt includes the date of sale, vendor's name, and registration number. Sales by vending machines are exempt from these requirements if they dispense taxable property for coins or bills up to twenty dollars and no single item exceeds ten dollars in price. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with individuals to pay taxes in installments to facilitate collection. Agreements remain valid unless information provided was inaccurate. They can also compromise on amounts due. SEC. 56. ACCOUNTING. Vendors must use the cash method for tax remittance. An accrual method election is allowed for reporting transactions. For bad debts, refer to section 11(g). SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. "Section 57 states that the exemption for taxable property or services used by a trade or business is not available if the business is not operated for profit. If the business has received gross payments exceeding certain expenses in 2 of the last 4 years, it is deemed to be engaged in for profit. Section 5 discusses the phase-out of the Internal Revenue Service." The text discusses the establishment of Excise Tax Bureau and Sales Tax Bureau within the Department of Treasury to administer excise and national sales taxes, respectively, after the repeal of income tax processing for years prior to fiscal year 2001. The Treasury establishes a Sales Tax Bureau to administer the national sales tax in required States and fulfill Federal duties related to the tax. Section 7801(b)(2) is amended to allow the appointment of up to 5 Assistant General Counsels. A modification is made for the tax imposed by section 1 and section 11 for taxable years ending June 30, 1999. For taxable years ending June 30, 1999, the tax imposed by section 1 and section 11 is modified. Dollar figures are adjusted for calendar year and fiscal year taxpayers. Tax rate schedules will be published by the Secretary. For taxable years ending June 30, 1999, tax rates are adjusted based on a specific ratio. The Secretary will publish tax rate schedules accordingly. The Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes starting January 1, 1999, as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 7 of the Act pertains to self-employment tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically subsection 1402(a), defines self-employment income as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid in furtherance of a business purpose, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income amounts from prior periods. Transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998. The transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998. Unused transition amounts and undeducted negative self-employment income amounts from prior periods are considered in the calculation. Conforming amendments are made to subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c), with subsections 1402(d) et seq. being renumbered as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SEC. 8. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The amendment to the Social Security Act includes defining the CPI increase percentage based on the Consumer Price Index for cost-of-living adjustments. The CPI increase percentage is calculated based on the Consumer Price Index and the national sales tax factor, exceeding the index for the most recent prior quarter. The national sales tax factor, defined as the sales tax rate divided by one minus the sales tax rate, exceeds the index for the most recent prior quarter. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating Payment: Eligible persons receive a compensating payment if they comply with the requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is someone who receives Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. Qualified fixed income payment is received by beneficiaries under a defined benefit plan. A qualified fixed income payment is a payment received by a beneficiary under a defined benefit plan or by an annuitant pursuant to an annuity contract with a bona fide insurance company. Such payments do not vary with investment performance, interest rates, or inflation. Payments from annuity contracts entered into after June 30, 1999, are not considered qualified fixed income payments. Payments under an annuity contract or defined benefit plan are not qualified fixed income payments if they vary with investment performance, interest rates, or inflation. Payments from annuity contracts entered into after June 30, 1999, are also not qualified fixed income payments. Additionally, payments from a defined benefit plan to a beneficiary who was a participant for less than 5 years are not qualified fixed income payments. The qualified fixed income payment amount is limited to $5,000 per year. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of qualified fixed income payments an eligible person is entitled to receive in the following year, not exceeding $5,000. The excess inflation rate is the difference between the consumer price index (all urban) over an 18-month period ending December 31, 2000, and the projected increase in the consumer price index reported in the Budget of the United States for Fiscal Year 1999. An application is required to receive compensating payments. The Office of Management and Budget projects an increase in the consumer price index for an 18-month period. Eligible individuals must apply for compensating payments through the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Payments will be received with Social Security benefits and funded from the general fund. The Secretary may require insurers to participate. Each person entitled to compensating payments will receive them with their Social Security benefits, funded from the general fund. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers to provide necessary information for determining qualified fixed income payment amounts. SEC. 10. INTEREST. Amends section 6621 of the Internal Revenue Code by reducing the interest rate. SEC. 11. SUPERMAJORITY REQUIRED TO RAISE RATE. Prohibits any bill that increases federal sales tax rate or reduces federal revenues without a two-thirds majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate.
